question_text: Molly flips a fair coin five times, and she is very surprised to flip a head each time. What is the probability she will flip a tail on her next flip of the coin? Express your answer as a common fraction.
response:
The probability that Molly will flip a tail on her next flip is still 1/2, because the coin is fair and the flips are independent events.

This makes sense because each time you flip a fair coin, the outcome (head or tail) has no influence on the outcome of the next flip. The probability of getting heads or tails on each flip is always 50%.

So, even though Molly got heads five times in a row, that's just luck! She should expect to get either heads or tails with equal probability on her next flip.
